Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ABI Innovation: Visualization and Statistics for Spatial Population Genomic Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Southern California and the University of California Davis are awarded collaborative grants to create methods and software to generate maps from genomic data, as well as to solve the related problem of placing samples of unknown origin on the map. Organisms that are more closely related to each other have more similar genomes. Often, an organism and its relatives live fairly nearby, so in principle genome similarity between many different organisms can be used to construct a map of the local geography. In this map, distances correspond to how easy it is for the organism to travel; so the map will display the landscape "as the organism sees it". Specifically, the methods developed here will construct these maps in a way to allow optimization of several different criteria, and will use randomized algorithms for pattern identification to allow efficient computation on large genomic datasets. The other, related suite of methods will use emerging tools from geostatistics to place other individuals on these maps, with rigorously quantified uncertainty.

The description of geographic patterns from genomic data, and location of unknown samples, will have many applications. These tools could be used to identify the origin of a newly invading parasite, or to identify key barriers dividing the range of an endangered species. They will be of interest for inferring ancestry, and might be used to locate, for instance, the likely home of a person's grandfather to within 100km or so. They can also be used to visualize the relationships between modern populations; for instance, of humans, whose modern distribution reflects a complex history of large- and small-scale migrations; or of other species for which we often know little about their migration ecology. The simple, interactive, animated graphics developed as part of this proposal will help give researchers a new way of displaying information
and contribute to the field of next-generation data visualization. To further enable effective communication of genetic results, short workshops will be offered both locally and at national meetings, with the post-doctoral fellow and/or graduate students hired through this proposal taking a leading role. The resulting tools will be distributed and discussed at http://ralphlab.usc.edu/ and http://gcbias.org/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All organisms are spread across geographical space, and geographic separation among individuals of the same species is often predictive of genetic differences amongst individuals. Understanding the impact of geography on the distribution of genetic variation is, therefore, often a key initial step in the analysis of population genomic data. Through this grant we developed a set of methods to understand the interplay of geography and genetic variation within populations. We showed how to estimate unknown geographic locations for individuals from genetic data and to visualize geo-genetic maps of set of individuals. We built on this approach we demonstrated how to identify discrete populations in the presence of geographic structure and created software to allowing investigators to learn about these patterns in their own data.

 

We also illustrated on fine spatial scales how long-term studies, such as the Florida Scrub Jay where individuals have been tracked over many generations and decades, could be used to understand the processes leading the geographic patterns of genetic variation. In addition, we developed a set of statistical tests to identify ecologically variables that have structured genetic variation while accounting for the background effect of geography.

 

Finally, through theoretical results we have shown how geographical separation could force populations to adapt by convergent genetic changes rather than a single adaptive solution spreading by migration. Building on this intuition we created methods to identify convergent genetic adaptations from genomic data and to identify the mode of convergent adaptation.
